ART 1A.title: Visual Literacy
ART 1A.description: An introductory survey of visual culture, encompassing art and film theory and practice, digital technologies, television, advertising and print media, with a special focus on current interdisciplinary methodologies.

ART 1C.title: Introduction to Contemporary Art
ART 1C.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring, Fall.
ART 1C.description: Symposium format course presents contemporary artists' creative projects in relation to recent developments in art and cross-disciplinary practices. Lectures by UCSB's Art Department faculty and also distinguished guests invited to expand on art, theory and cultural production.

ART 7A.title: The Intersections of Art and Life
ART 7A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring, Summer.
ART 7A.description: Explores art in relation to time-based activity and integration with everyday life. Conceptual introduction to authorship, authenticity, and narrative through exercises and examples of performance, video, film, book, arts, sound, digital media, and interactive/chance derived work.

ART 7B.title: Introduction to Contemporary Practice I: Image Studies
ART 7B.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
ART 7B.description: The study of visual perception and image-making across visual art disciplines, both material and digital. Studio assignments are combined with related critical theory, historical practice, current strategies, and new evolutions.

ART 7C.title: Introduction to Contemporary Practice II: Spatial Studies
ART 7C.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
ART 7C.description: The study of spatial art in many forms, including material, interactive and dynamic digital. Studio assignments are combined with related critical theory, historical practice, current strategies and new evolutions.

ART 7D.title: Introduction to Contemporary Practice III: Art, Science and   Technologies
ART 7D.description: The study of foundations of digital and technological arts in all forms, including history, theory and practice of optical, kinetic, interactive, interdisciplinary and systems-oriented art. Lectures and assignments introduce concepts, methods, movements and practitioners that have shaped the fields.

ART 10.title: Introduction to Painting
ART 10.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units, but only 4 units can beapplied to the major. Course materials fee charged.
ART 10.description: Traditional and contemporary painting assignments designed to provide a strong foundation in fundamental 2D image making. Media include acrylic and oil painting methods.

ART 12.title: Beginning Spatial Practices
ART 12.comments: Open to non-majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units but only 4 units can be applied to the major. Course materials fee charged.
ART 12.description: Introduction to the challenges, strategies, and techniques of 3D artmaking within the expanding fields of traditional and contemporary sculpture.

ART 14.title: Lower-Division Print
ART 14.comments: Open to non-majors. Open to non-majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units but only 4 units can be applied to the major. Letter grade required for majors. Course materials fee charged.
ART 14.description: Introduction to making prints. Emphasis on technical fundamentals and conceptual aspects of graphic arts. "Print" incorporates hand produced mechanically or photographically reproduced, and electronically replicated media.

ART 18.title: Lower-Division Drawing
ART 18.comments: Letter grade required for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximumof 8 units but only 4 units can be applied to the major. Open to non-majors. Course materials fee charged.
ART 18.description: Introduction to two-dimensional representation with various drawing media, including structural and symbolic implications of the human form. Emphasis on organization of vision and thought.

ART 19.title: Lower-Division Photography
ART 19.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units, but only 4 units can be applied to the major.
ART 19.description: Introduction to photography-based image-making that may include still photography, new approaches to documentary, online projects, explorations in visual narrative, mixed media, social and public practices. Instruction in digital imagine and printing.

ART 22.title: Introduction to Computer Programming in the Arts
ART 22.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units, but only 4 units may be applied to the major.
ART 22.description: Using a project-based approach, the basic components of web development and computer programming are explored in different markup and programming languages such as HTML/CSS, JavaScript, and Processing. The class is intended to create a general understanding of computer programming, its use and cultural implications, as well as provide a foundation for utilizing programming in a wide range of projects, from traditional to new media.

ART 32.title: Introduction to Digital Video
ART 32.description: Introduction to digital video production including camera work, editing, sound, and distribution platforms. Conceptual and technical concerns relevant to video in the evolving theater of contemporary art and culture.

ART 100.title: Intermediate Contemporary Painting Issues
ART 100.prereq_description: Art 10; Art 1A or 7B or Upper Division standing or Instructor Approval
ART 100.comments: Open to non-majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units with instructor approval. Letter grade required for majors. Course materialsfee charged.
ART 100.description: Various projects designed to assist the understanding and development of contemporary painting practices. Supplemented with slide lectures and class critique. Additional self-directed projects, sketch books, experimentation, and independent research are encouraged.

ART 101.title: Advanced Contemporary Painting Issues
ART 101.prereq_description: Art 10,100; 1A or 7B or Upper Division standing or Instructor Approval
ART 101.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Course materials fee charged.
ART 101.description: Special critique-based class addressing current issues in contemporary painting. 'Painting' will be used in broadest sense including traditional methods, and digital painting (digitally manipulated images as source), installation and inter-media practices utilizing paint as dominant medium.

ART 102AAZZ.title: Digital Media Tool Box: Concepts and Skills
ART 102AAZZ.prereq_description: Art 22, 7D; 1A or Upper Division or Instructor Approval
ART 102AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
ART 102AAZZ.description: A project based course with an emphasis on technical skills within the digital media arts context. Topics may include telecommunications, wireless, database aesthetics, networks, interactivity, digital 3D, virtual reality, immersive environments, algorithmic aesthetics, visualization, media theory and others. Topic to be determined by instructor.

ART 105AAZZ.title: Intermediate Spatial Practices
ART 105AAZZ.prereq_description: Art 12; 1A or 7C or Upper Division or Instructor Approval
ART 105AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units with instructor approval. Letter-grade required for majors. Course materials fee charged.
ART 105AAZZ.description: Designed to develop student knowledge and proficiency of material and method, cultivating both manual and conceptual skill-levels in three-dimensional practices. Course focus varies by quarter, but includes a variety of approaches to material practices and engages students in the role of spatial awareness and production within contemporary art.

ART 106AAZZ.title: Advanced Spatial Practices
ART 106AAZZ.prereq_description: Art 12; 1A or 7C or Upper Division or Instructor Approval
ART 106AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Letter grade required for majors. Course materials fee charged.
ART 106AAZZ.description: Advanced study and investigation of new forms and spatial practices. Individual and group projects may encompass formal and collaborative research as well as multi-disciplinary production that engages new and exploratory practices, such as interactive and performative media, public art, social design at the intersection of architecture, urbanism and contemporary art. Course content detailed in syllabus each quarter.

ART 106W.title: Introduction to 2D/3D Visualizations in Architecture
ART 106W.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; open to majors only.
ART 106W.description: Develops skills in reading, interpreting, and visualizing 3D objects and spaces by offering exercises in sketching, perspective, orthographic projections, isometric drawings, and manual rendering practices. Relevant for those interested in history of architecture, sculpture, and such spatial practices as installations and public art.

ART 110.title: Intermediate Print
ART 110.prereq_description: Art 14, 18; 1A or 7B or Upper Division or Instructor Approval
ART 110.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Course materials fee charged.
ART 110.description: Continued refinement of skills in service of ink and digital print production. Emphasis on intermedia aspects of image and text and the sequential use of pictorial information. Areas of specific focus to include electronic multiples, relief printing, and artists' books.

ART 111PP.title: Public Practice Arts: Digital Intermedia
ART 111PP.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
ART 111PP.description: The use of digital and print-based media to create site-responsive public projects including unsanctioned, permission based, and speculative works. The investigation of the evolving nature and use of public space and its interrelations of individual, social, architectural/built, and infrastructure conditions. Projects are executed both on and off campus.

ART 112.title: Artists' Books
ART 112.comments: Designed for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
ART 112.description: An investigation of the book as an art form. Based on conventional media, artists' books encompass a variety of methods, techniques, and ideas. Assigned and self-directed projects using traditional and innovative practices, combining reading with pictorial and tactile experience.

ART 113.title: Experimental Video & Animation
ART 113.comments: Concurrently offered with ART 213. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring.
ART 113.description: The development of independent, innovative projects that utilize digital video and/or post-production and hybrid means to create video-works for screens and surfaces, including projection, installation, distributed platforms. Projects may employ a variety of strategies and methodologies in concept, production, and presentation. Broad exposure to contemporary and pioneering video/film, with an emphasis on experimentation in substance and form.

ART 117.title: Intermediate Drawing
ART 117.prereq_description: Art 18; 1A or 7B or Upper Division or Instructor Approval
ART 117.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units with instructor approval. Course materials fee charged.
ART 117.description: Continuing investigation into the challenges of two-  dimensional representation. Course focus to depend on instructor, but may include structural and symbolic implications of the human form, historical and contemporary strategies of visual analysis, and exploration into experimental media.

ART 118.title: Advanced Drawing
ART 118.prereq_description: Art 18, 117; 1A or Upper Division or Instructor Approval
ART 118.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Letter grade required for majors. Course materials fee charged.
ART 118.description: Special studies in drawing utilizing particular faculty interests and/or special departmental facilities. Designed for majors.

ART 120AAZZ.title: Intermediate Photography
ART 120AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units with instructor approval. Letter grade required for majors. Course materials fee charged.
ART 120AAZZ.description: Continued refinement of traditional photographic technique, and development of photography as an artmaking tool. Course to range by instructor, but may include photo narrative, journalism, fashion, artists' books, desktop publishing, web design, time-based work, and intermedia collaborations.

ART 121.title: Advanced Photography
ART 121.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Letter grade required for majors.
ART 121.description: Special studies in photography utilizing faculty interests and/or special departmental facilities. Exact nature of course content to be specified in the Department of Art Studio syllabus.

ART 122AAZZ.title: Advanced Topics in Digital Media
ART 122AAZZ.prereq_description: Art 22, 7D; 1A or Upper Division or Instructor Approval
ART 122AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
ART 122AAZZ.description: An advanced project based course in digital media arts. Students are expected to have relevant conceptual, aesthetic, and technological grounding in digital media. Topic to be determined by instructor.

ART 123.title: Papermaking
ART 123.description: Introduction to historical and contemporary methods of handmade papermaking leading to innovative uses of handmade paper as an integral part of art forms.

ART 124.title: ARTISTS' FUTURES: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICES II
ART 124.prereq_description: Must be in upper division standing.
ART 124.description: Dives into the wide range of professionalism for artists within and adjacent to the art world. The class provides students the necessary skills to advance their work as emerging artists, addressing portfolio preparation and artist opportunities like graduate education, exhibitions, residencies, and grants. Also introduces students to the wide variety of careers available to artists and provides them with building blocks to move forward within these careers. Guest speakers illuminate opportunities in several fields including curatorial practice, design, marketing, art business, education, and non-profit work.

ART 125.description: Developments in American and European art since 1950 with an emphasis on the most recent decades. Focus ranges from the post-war impact of the New York School, Pop Art, Minimalism and Conceptualism to more recent, "postmodern" trends.

ART 126.title: Introduction to Contemporary Theory
ART 126.description: A basic beginning survey of contemporary art, film and media theory, focusing specifically on: realism, formalism, semiotics, phenomenology, psychoanalysis, feminism, Marxism, gender/queer studies, poststructuralism, post-colonial theory and broader issues of authorship, narratology, postmodernism, and multiculturalism.

ART 130.title: Visual Arts as Culture
ART 130.description: Exploration of visual arts and culture, including the evolving social and practical parameters of technologically produced images and the shifting arenas of ideology, analysis, and criticism.

ART 132.title: Digital Video
ART 132.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Letter grade required for majors.
ART 132.description: The making and use of video in contemporary art. Hands-on production and post production are combined with viewing, critique, and discussion topics, including cultural prominence and future trends. Single and multiple channel, installation, and integration with other media are all encouraged.

ART 133.title: Memory: An Interdisciplinary Exploration
ART 133.description: Introduces students to the trans-disciplinary fields of memory and migration through interdisciplinary collaboration. Course responsibilities include class participation, a midterm essay and a final interdisciplinary project. This course draws upon the connections between neuroscience, arts and studies of human migration.

ART 133M.title: Memory: An Interdisciplinary Exploration
ART 133M.description: Introduces students to the trans-disciplinary fields of memory and migration through interdisciplinary collaboration. Course responsibilities include class participation, a midterm essay and a final interdisciplinary project. This course draws upon the connections between neuroscience, arts and studies of human migration.

ART 134.title: Performance
ART 134.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Letter grade required for majors.
ART 134.description: A workshop introduction to the forms, styles, and strategies of contemporary performance art, which may involve the use of the body, space, narrative, audience, object, installation, and multimedia.

ART 134P.title: Performance & Environment
ART 134P.prereq_description: OR Upper Division OR Instructor Approval
ART 134P.comments:
Majors may repeat for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Minors May repeat for credit max 8 units. Letter grade required for majors..
Repeat Comments: Majors may repeat for credit to a maximum of 16 units. Minors May repeat for credit max 8 units. Letter grade required for majors.
ART 134P.description: This workshop introduces students to artists in the field of environmental and ecological activism. Students develop projects that address environmental justice, landscape and place using performance, video, installation and other conceptual strategies.

ART 136.title: Personal Narrative
ART 136.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
ART 136.description: Intensive writing-based workshop designed for formulating and producing artwork based on one's own personal experiences and histories. Experimentation and expansion into other artistic media are encouraged.

ART 137.title: Spoken Word
ART 137.description: A workshop introduction to the use of voice as an artistic medium, with emphasis on personal monologue, and improvisation.

ART 177.title: Art and Science of Aerospace Culture
ART 177.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
ART 177.description: Interdisciplinary course/seminar/practice that explores technological, aesthetic, cultural, and political aspects of the space side of the aerospace complex. Design history,  space complex aesthetics, cinema intersections, imaging/telecommunications, human spaceflight history, reduced/alternating gravity experimentation, space  systems design/utilization.

ART 179C.title: Mediatechnology
ART 179C.comments:
Same course as GER 179C and C LIT 179C.
Repeat Comments: Since this is a crosslisted course, this course may not be repeated for additional credit.
ART 179C.description: Telegraph, telephone, phonograph, and film techniques that have engendered new forms of representation, communications, and thinking. Course studies the impact of these transformations in literature and on literature. Taught in English.

ART 185AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Art
ART 185AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.

ART 185B.title: ARTISTS' FUTURES: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICES B
ART 185B.prereq_description: Open to art majors only; Open to seniors and juniors only.
ART 185B.comments: Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with Art CS 106.
ART 185B.description: This course dives into the wide range of professionalism for artists within and adjacent to the art world. Provides students the necessary skills to advance their work as emerging artists, addressing portfolio preparation and artist opportunities like graduate education, exhibitions, residencies, and grants. Also introduces students to the wide variety of careers available to artists and provide them with building blocks to move forward within these careers. Guest speakers will illuminate opportunities in several fields including curatorial practice, design, marketing, art business, education, and non-profit work.

ART 189A.title: Capstone Design Lab
ART 189A.comments:
Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with ME 189A. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
Repeat Comments: Not open to students who have completed ME 189A.
ART 189A.description: Students in Art 189A-B-C will be working in teams together with mechanical engineering students on a mechanical engineering capstone design project. The teams work under the direction of a faculty advisor in mechanical engineering, and to a lesser extent an advisor from the art department (and possibly an industrial sponsor) to tackle an engineering design project. Engineering communication, such as reports and oral presentations, are covered. Emphasis on practical, hands-on experience, and the integration of analytical and design skills. Students should aim to commit to taking A, B and C in order to work with their team from conception to finalization of a project. This lab is the first of three the series.

ART 189B.title: Capstone Design Lab
ART 189B.comments:
Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with ME 189B. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
Repeat Comments: Not open to students who have completed ME 189B.

ART 189C.title: Capstone Design Lab
ART 189C.comments:
Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with ME 189C. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
Repeat Comments: Not open to students who have completed ME 189C.
ART 189C.description: Students in Art 189A-B-C will be working in teams together with mechanical engineering students on a mechanical engineering capstone design project. The teams work under the direction of a faculty advisor in mechanical engineering, and to a lesser extent an advisor from the art department (and possibly an industrial sponsor) to tackle an engineering design project. Engineering communication, such as reports and oral presentations, are covered. Emphasis on practical, hands-on experience, and the integration of analytical and design skills. Students should aim to commit to taking A, B and C in order to work with their team from conception to finalization of a project. This lab is third of three in the series.

ART 192AAZZ.title: Internship in Art
ART 192AAZZ.comments:
Students must have a 3.0 overall GPA.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units, but only 4 units can beapplied to the major.
ART 192AAZZ.description: Opportunities in applied learning related to visual art through local museums, art galleries, and other art related organizations or institutions. Students work under the direction of the faculty sponsor who maintains contact with the supervisor for whom the student is interning.

ART 194.title: Special Group Studies
ART 194.description: A means of making special studies or meeting special curricular problems.

ART 196.title: Honors Seminar
ART 196.prereq_description: L&S and CCS Art majors only; upper-division standing; acceptance into
ART 196.comments: Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Students must have a 3.5 grade-point average in the major and at least a 3.0 grade-point average overall.
ART 196.description: Seminar designed to focus on criticism of current art work. A total of 12 units in this course required to complete honors program. Completion of seminar units followed by public exhibition of work accomplished.

ART 199.title: Independent Studies
ART 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in Art;
ART 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding three quarters andare limited to 5 units per quarter (without petition) and 16 units total in all 199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
ART 199.description: Independent studies. Advanced independent or collaborative work in consultation with individual faculty; individual tutorial.

ART 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Art
ART 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division students only; consent of instructor and department.
ART 199RA.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and arelimited to 5 units per quarter (without petition) and 16 units total in all 199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
ART 199RA.description: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.

ART 213.title: Experimental Video & Animation
ART 213.comments: Concurrently offered with Art 113. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring.
ART 213.description: The development of independent, innovative projects that utilize digital and/or post-production and hybrid means to create video-works for screens and surfaces, including projection, installation, distributed platforms. Projects may employ a variety of strategies and methodologies in concept, production, and presentation. Broad exposure to contemporary and pioneering video/film, with an emphasis on experimentation in substance and form.

ART 242.title: Reading and Research in Art
ART 242.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
ART 242.description: Readings and research in topics of a historical and contemporary nature.

ART 244.title: Graduate Seminar in Critique
ART 244.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
ART 244.description: A seminar focusing on criticism of current art work.

ART 245.title: Graduate Theory Seminar
ART 245.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
ART 245.description: In-depth look at contemporary media and art discourse framed through a wide range of theoretical approaches: formalism, structuralism, phenomenology, psychoanalysis, Marxism, gender and queer studies, poststructuralism, postcolonial theory, deconstruction, issues of authorship, narratology, and multiculturalism. Specific content varies with instructor.

ART 246.title: Post MFA
ART 246.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
ART 246.description: Seminar will address strategies for sustaining creative practice and dialog for graduating MFAs. The politics and poetics of interfacing with institutions, art professionals, peers and community groups through direct and indirect means. The presentation, distribution, and/or sale of your work through commercial and non-commercial means. The business of being an artist including taxes, insurance, studio space. Featuring faculty and guest speakers.

ART 260.title: Graduate Seminar in Visual Arts
ART 260.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
ART 260.description: A means of making special studies and meeting special curricular problems.

ART 261.title: All Faculty Graduate Seminar
ART 261.description: Symposium format course presents contemporary artists' creative projects in relation to recent developments in art and cross-disciplinary practices. Lectures by faculty from UCSB's Art Department supplemented by distinguished guests invited to expand on art, theory and cultural production.

ART 591A.title: Directed Study in Visual Arts Education
ART 591A.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

ART 593MS.title: M.F.A. Thesis Project
ART 593MS.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

ART 594.title: Special Studies in Art
ART 594.description: A means of making special studies and meeting special curricular problems.

ART 595.title: Direct Historical Reading and Research
ART 595.description: Independent research involving extensive reading and written essay on a particular period, artist, or body of work with a historical context.
